definitions.meaning: When something unfortunate happens, it can be called a 'tough break.'
examples: It was a tough break for us when Caroline quit. She was one of our top performers.

definitions.meaning: To be "ahead of the curve" means to be more advanced than the competition.
examples: We're investing a lot of money in research and development so we can stay ahead of the curve.

definitions.meaning: To be "ahead of the pack" means to be better or more successful than the competition.
examples: If we want to stay ahead of the pack, we're going to have to work really hard and continue to innovate.

definitions.meaning: 'At stake' means at risk.
examples: I'm a little nervous about giving this presentation. There's a lot at stake.
About 3000 jobs are at stake if the company closes down.

definitions.meaning: making you feel frightened or nervous
examples: an intimidating array of weapons
an intimidating manner
She can be very intimidating when she's angry.

definitions.meaning: to stick firmly
examples: A smooth, dry surface helps the tiles adhere to the wall.

definitions.meaning: a difficult or unlucky situation or event
examples: She was always cheerful in adversity.
The road to happiness is paved with adversities.

definitions.meaning: used to tell someone to be patient because the thing they are eager for will happen when the time is right:
examples: Be patient, you'll hear the result all in good time.

definitions.meaning: having two opposing feelings at the same time, or being uncertain about how you feel
examples: I felt very ambivalent about leaving home.
He has fairly ambivalent feelings towards his father.
an ambivalent attitude to exercise

definitions.meaning: to make someone have strong feelings of shock or of disapproval
examples: I was appalled at/by the lack of staff in the hospital.
The state of the kitchen appalled her.
He witnessed some appalling acts of barbarism during the war.
Conditions in the prison are said to be appalling.
Your table manners are appalling - don't you know how to use a knife and fork?
After her appalling behaviour, we had no option but to dismiss her.
The standard of cleanliness in some of these restaurants is frankly appalling.

definitions.meaning: Someone who is assertive behaves confidently and is not frightened to say what they want or believe
examples: If you really want the promotion, you'll have to be more assertive.
I've had to train myself to be more assertive at work.
Don't let him boss you around like that - try to be a bit more assertive!
In difficult situations like that, it's important to be assertive without getting angry or aggressive.
I've become a lot more assertive as I've got older, and will no longer put up with bad service.
He taught his children to be assertive and to stand up to the bullies.

definitions.meaning: the power to control or demand obedience from others
examples: The police have no legal authority in these disputes.
We have to find someone in authority (= a position of power).

definitions.meaning: An authority is someone with official responsibility for a particular area of activity
examples: government/church authorities

definitions.meaning: The authorities are the police or other government officials
examples: No attacks were reported to the authorities.

definitions.meaning: An authority on a subject is an expert on it
examples: an authority on immigration law

definitions.meaning: to be quick to understand and react to things:
examples: I didn't sleep well last night and I'm not really on the ball today.

definitions.meaning: to be in a hurry:
examples: I'd love to stop and talk, but I'm pressed for time.

definitions.meaning: to be patient and wait while someone does something
examples: If you'll just bear with me for a moment, I'll find you a copy of the drawings.

definitions.meaning: an act of breaking a law, promise, agreement, or relationship
examples: They felt that our discussions with other companies constituted a breach of/in our agreement.
He was sued for breach of contract.
There have been serious security breaches (= breaks in our security system).

definitions.meaning: (an example of) illegal noisy or violent behaviour in a public place
to be breaking a particular law or rule
examples: The theatre was in breach of the safety laws for having no fire doors.

definitions.meaning: a hole that is made in a wall or in another structure being used for protection during an attack
examples: A cannon ball had made a breach in their castle walls.

definitions.meaning: to break a law, promise, agreement, or relationship
examples: They breached the agreement they had made with their employer.

definitions.meaning: to make an opening in a wall or fence, especially in order to attack someone or something behind it
examples: Their defences were easily breached.

definitions.meaning: a situation or event that is unpleasant or disappointing
examples: Waiting all day at the airport is a real bummer.

definitions.meaning: by a great amount:
examples: She is by far the best student in the class.

definitions.meaning: not having enough money
examples: cash-strapped universities
Working during study is a fact of life for most cash-strapped students.

definitions.meaning: to ask for a price for something
examples: I think they charge too much for football tickets.

definitions.meaning: to buy something and agree to pay for it later
examples: I didn’t have any cash, so I charged the food.

definitions.meaning: to accuse someone of something, esp. to officially accuse someone of a crime
examples: He was charged with resisting arrest.

definitions.meaning: to move forward quickly, esp. to attack
examples: When the batter was hit with the pitch, he dropped his bat and charged the pitcher.

definitions.meaning: to put electrical energy into a storage device such as a battery
examples: It takes several hours for my laptop’s batteries to charge.

definitions.meaning: to instruct (the people deciding a legal case) what the law is in a particular case
examples: The judge charged the jury before deliberations began.
How much do you charge for hiring out a bicycle for a week?
He charges anywhere from $20 to $50 for a haircut and blow-dry.
The restaurant charges shockingly high prices for its food.
My plumber charges £20 an hour.
The policy of charging air travellers for vegetarian meals proved unpopular.

definitions.meaning: responsibility for the control of something or the care of someone
examples: Marilyn agreed to take charge of fundraising.

definitions.meaning: the amount of explosive to be fired at one time
the amount of electricity that an electrical device stores or carries
A positive or negative electrical charge is a basic characteristic of matter.
invite on a date (as in a courtship)
examples: Brian asked Judy out to dinner and a movie.
She's asked Steve out to the cinema this evening.
You should ask her out sometime.

definitions.meaning: explode
examples: The racing car blew up after it crashed into the fence.

definitions.meaning: If a machine or vehicle breaks down, it stops working
examples: Our car broke down and we had to push it off the road.
The school bus broke down and had to be towed to the nearest garage.
Oh no - has your washing machine broken down again?
I'm worried that his car has broken down, or worse still, that he's had an accident.
If the central heating breaks down again, I will refuse to pay the repair bill.
Our dishwasher broke down just a month after the guarantee had expired.
Our car broke down at the side of the highway in the snowstorm.

definitions.meaning: force entry to a building
examples: Thieves broke into our office downtown and stole the computers.
Somebody broke in last night and stole our stereo.

definitions.meaning: to force your way into something
examples: He’s had his apartment broken into twice.
The firemen had to break into the room to rescue the children.

definitions.meaning: to look at someone or something in order to make sure that they are safe, correct, etc.
examples: You will need to check on your new employees' qualifications.

definitions.meaning: to mention something as proof for a theory or as a reason why something has happened, or to speak or write words taken from a written work
examples: He cited a study of the devices as proof that the company knew they were dangerous.
Scientists cite this experiment as their main support for this theory.

definitions.meaning: To cite someone else’s words when speaking or writing is to use them
examples: If you cite too many writers, readers will wonder if you have any ideas of your own.

definitions.meaning: In law, a person or organization which is cited is named in a legal action
examples: The mine operator was cited with 33 violations of federal safety standards.

definitions.meaning: to praise someone publicly for something the person has done
examples: He was cited for bravery.

definitions.meaning: to make something clearer or easier to understand
examples: I hope this analysis will clarify the debate.
Talking it through with you has helped me to clarify my own thinking about the problem.

definitions.meaning: to admit that something is true, or to allow something
examples: Officials concede (that) the plan isn’t the best one.

definitions.meaning: If you concede in a competition, you admit that you have lost
examples: She conceded (the election) yesterday.

definitions.meaning: to persuade someone that something false is the truth, or to keep the truth hidden from someone for your own advantage
examples: The company deceived customers by selling old computers as new ones.
The sound of the door closing deceived me into thinking they had gone out.

definitions.meaning: to refuse to accept the truth
examples: She thinks he'll come back, but she's deceiving herself.
Anyway, I can't deceive him - it's against all my principles.
He repudiated the allegation that he had tried to deceive them.
I suspect these statistics flatter to deceive.
What really angered her was the dirty underhand way they had deceived her.
They deceived us into thinking they would come back later with our money.

definitions.meaning: making choices quickly and surely, without having any doubts
examples: In an emergency, decisive action is called for.

definitions.meaning: to interrupt when someone else is talking
examples: As she was talking, he suddenly broke in, saying, "That's a lie."
The TV station broke in to report the news of the president's death.

definitions.meaning: make unhappy
examples: This sad music is bringing me down.

definitions.meaning: to care for a child until he or she is an adult, often giving him or her particular beliefs
examples: She was brought up by her grandmother.
They brought her up (as/to be) a Catholic.
David was brought up to respect authority.
My grandparents brought me up after my parents died.
He was brought up on a diet of political propaganda from birth.
My father was a real authoritarian so we were brought up very strictly.
She brought up her children in just the same way her mother did.
Ann was born and brought up in Ealing.
He's got some funny ideas about how to bring up children.

definitions.meaning: showing the strong desire to follow a particular plan of action even if it is difficult
examples: a very determined young man
She had a determined look on her face.
I’m determined to finish this book today.

definitions.meaning: extremely loving and loyal
examples: In real life the star of the film is a devoted husband and father.
The shop has a small but devoted following.
His most devoted fans think of Morrissey as a sort of god.
The band's latest album is very poor although devoted fans might enjoy it.
He described his client as a devoted family man.

definitions.meaning: careful and serious in your work, or done in a careful and determined way
examples: a diligent worker
They made diligent efforts to carry out their programs.

definitions.meaning: to start to talk about a particular subject
examples: She's always bringing up her health problems.
My mother walks out of the room when my father brings up sports.

definitions.meaning: to vomit something
examples: She was crying so much I thought she'd bring up her breakfast.
He drank so much that he brought his dinner up in the toilet.
The meeting seemed to be going well until Charles brought up the issue of holiday pay.
He's forever bringing up the past.
The evening was going well until someone brought up the subject of politics.
She would start talking about something else whenever he brought up the subject of marriage.
It was neither the time nor place to bring up the issue of religion.

definitions.meaning: phone many different places/people
examples: We called around but we weren't able to find the car part we needed.

definitions.meaning: to cancel, to decide that a planned event, especially a sports event, will not happen, or to end an activity because it is no longer useful or possible
examples: Tomorrow's match has been called off because of the icy weather.
The police have called off the search for the missing child until dawn tomorrow.
Jason called the wedding off because he wasn't in love with his fiancé.
They've called off the wedding.
We had to call off the party because of his health.
The wedding was planned for June and they've just called the whole thing off.
Is it too late to call it off?
They've had to call off the match at the last minute.

definitions.meaning: to reach someone or something by moving faster than the other person or thing
examples: She is really fast, and I couldn’t catch up with her.
fig. We’re a young, growing company, and we’re trying to catch up to the competition.
You'll have to run faster than that if you want to catch up with Marty.

definitions.meaning: to talk with someone you know in order to exchange news or information
examples: By the time coffee came, R.J. and Angelo had caught up a little bit.

definitions.meaning: to tell people unpleasant or shocking personal information about someone
examples: She agreed to dish the dirt on her ex-husband for a large fee.

definitions.meaning: to give something or someone a particular name, esp. describing what you think of that person or thing
examples: At age 21 Ella Fitzgerald was dubbed "The First Lady of Swing."

definitions.meaning: an effort or attempt to do something
examples: Writing is a very different endeavor than teaching.

definitions.meaning: to try to do something
examples: I endeavored to explain the legal consequences of his action.

definitions.meaning: one of the parts or features of something
examples: There’s always one facet of my golf game that isn’t working.

definitions.meaning: a false belief
examples: It is a common fallacy that only men are good at math.

definitions.meaning: to make a person or place clean and tidy
examples: We'll go out as soon as I've cleaned up the kitchen.
I need to clean up (= clean myself or the place where I am) before we go out.
Clean yourself up a bit before dinner.
Please clean up your bedroom before you go outside.

definitions.meaning: to find something unexpectedly
examples: He came across some of his old love letters in his wife's desk.
I came across these old photos when I was cleaning the closet.

definitions.meaning: to offer to give help
examples: Nobody has come forward yet with information about the accident.
The woman came forward with her husband's fingerprints.

definitions.meaning: to be born, got from, or made in a particular place
examples: She comes from Italy.
Some of the best wines come from France.
Does that quote come from Shakespeare?
She could hear banging coming from the room upstairs.
Where will the money for the project come from?
The art of origami comes from Asia.
He's American but his family come/comes from Ireland.
They come from a privileged/wealthy background.
The two passenger trains involved in the accident had both come from southwest London.
His family originally came from Ireland, but resettled in the US in the 19th century.
I could hear loud snores coming from Jim's bedroom.

definitions.meaning: rely on
examples: I am counting on you to make dinner while I am out.
You can always count on Michael in a crisis.
I can count on my parents to help me.

definitions.meaning: the ability to judge correctly what is going to happen
examples: She had the foresight to sell her house just before prices came down.

definitions.meaning: to begin to do something
examples: We’d like to help but we’re not sure what’s the best way to go about it.

cards.text: have nothing to do with someone/something

definitions.meaning: to not involve someone or something:
examples: This argument has nothing to do with me.
Much of the bill has nothing to do with civil rights.

definitions.meaning: the ability to understand an event or situation only after it has happened
examples: With (the benefit/wisdom of) hindsight, I should have taken the job.
In hindsight, it would have been better to wait.

cards.text: His brain was not wired for physics.

definitions.meaning: Physics is very difficult for him.
to draw a line through something you have written, usually because it is wrong
examples: If you think it's wrong, cross it out and write it again.
Please cross out your old address and write your new one.

definitions.meaning: to spend less, do less, or use less of something
examples: The government has announced plans to cut back on defence spending by 10 percent next year.
If exercise is causing you pain, you should cut back.
My doctor wants me to cut back on sweets and fatty foods.

definitions.meaning: do again
examples: The teacher told him to do the assignment over.
My teacher wants me to do my essay over because she doesn't like my topic.

definitions.meaning: to wear more formal clothes than you usually wear
examples: You don’t need to dress up for the party.
It's a fancy restaurant so we have to dress up.

definitions.meaning: to come for a visit, esp. without having received an invitation for a specific time
examples: Drop in whenever you’re in the neighborhood.
I might drop in/by/over for tea sometime this week.

definitions.meaning: To take somebody wherever he needs usualy by car.
responsible for something or someone:
examples: Who’s in charge here?
The teacher put me in charge of organizing the project.

definitions.meaning: to experience something, usually something unpleasant, as a result of actions you have taken
examples: to incur debts/fines/bills
The play has incurred the wrath/anger of both audiences and critics.
Please detail any costs/expenses incurred by you in attending the interview.

definitions.meaning: to continue living after a point at which you might easily have died:
examples: Since his cancer was diagnosed, he feels as if he's living on borrowed time.
It is unlikely that serious decisions will made by a CEO living on borrowed time.

definitions.meaning: to act as if something is not serious, esp. when it is serious:
examples: They've both had knee injuries, but the two friends make light of their weaknesses.

definitions.meaning: to take or take hold of something or someone suddenly
examples: Let's grab some coffee on the way out.
Let's grab some lunch on the way.
Let’s grab a sandwich (= get it and eat it quickly) before we leave.
I grabbed the rope and pulled myself out of the water.
We’d better get there early, or someone else will grab the best seats (= take them first).
Suddenly, she grabbed me when the movie got scary.

definitions.meaning: a flat piece of wood, stone, etc. that forms the base of a window or door
examples: I often like to sit on a window sill and smoke out the window.

definitions.meaning: If something that you have been looking for turns up, you find it unexpectedly
examples: The missing letter eventually turned up inside a book.
I expect a new job will turn up soon.
We don't have a house at the moment, but I'm sure something will turn up.
This opportunity turned up at just the right time for me.
I thought she wouldn't be able to make it but then she suddenly turned up.
The boss is having a party this weekend. I hope a lot of people turn up.
I was supposed to have an interview yesterday, but the guy didn't turn up.

definitions.meaning: a path with a hard surface on one or both sides of a road, that people walk on
examples: Keep on the sidewalk, Rosie, there's a good girl.

definitions.meaning: a large building that is divided into apartments
examples: We have a lot of underground parking. Especially under apartment buildings.

definitions.meaning: not easily or quickly noticed or seen, or not attracting attention
examples: This type of bird is very inconspicuous because of its dull feathers.
At parties, he always stands in a corner and tries to look inconspicuous.

definitions.meaning: unpleasant, unkind, cruel, or more severe than is necessary
examples: harsh criticism
The children had had a harsh upbringing.
We thought the punishment was rather harsh for such a minor offence.
"There is no alternative," she said in a harsh voice.
He said some harsh words (= spoke unkindly) about his brother.

definitions.meaning: too strong, bright, loud, etc.
examples: harsh chemicals/lighting
The harsh light revealed every crevice and wrinkle in his face.
In a harsh economic climate, raises for teachers have become a lightning rod for criticism.
The book confronts the harsh social and political realities of the world today.
The prison sentence seemed rather harsh, considering the triviality of the offence.
The people rebelled against the harsh new government.

definitions.meaning: to make something known publicly, or to show something that was hidden
examples: The company has disclosed profits of over £200 million.
The police have disclosed that two officers are under internal investigation.
She refused to disclose any details of the plan.
He received an anonymous letter threatening to disclose details of his affair if he didn't pay the money.
This information cannot be disclosed without authorization from a minister.
They made an agreement not to disclose any details.
The journalist refused to disclose her sources.

definitions.meaning: Something or someone that is indispensable is so good or important that you could not manage without it, him, or her
examples: This book is an indispensable resource for researchers.
His long experience at the United Nations makes him indispensable to the talks.

definitions.meaning: extremely useful
examples: The new job will provide you with invaluable experience.
Such data will prove invaluable to/for researchers.

definitions.meaning: Exorbitant prices, demands, etc. are much too large
examples: The bill for dinner was exorbitant.

definitions.meaning: work such as painting, repairing, and cleaning that is done to make a building look new again
examples: The museum has undergone a £15 million refurbishment.

definitions.meaning: on the wrong track; completely wrong.
examples: I think you're way off base. Try again. Sorry. You are way off. You should just give up.

definitions.meaning: to take the place of something lost or damaged or to compensate for something bad with something good
examples: No amount of money can make up for the death of a child.
This year's good harvest will make up for last year's bad one.
He bought me dinner to make up for being so late the day before.
She gave him a bottle of wine to make up for missing his birthday.
I worked extra hours to make up for the time I had missed.
You need to do something to make up for your rudeness.
How can I ever make up for the pain I caused them?
I'm taking extra lessons to make up for the time I missed.

definitions.meaning: able to change easily from one activity to another or able to be used for many different purposes
examples: He's a very versatile young actor who's as happy in highbrow dramas as he is in TV comedies.
A leather jacket is a timeless and versatile garment that can be worn in all seasons.
This jacket is very versatile - you can dress it up for the evening.
He is a very versatile actor.
We want all our staff to be versatile.
This is a very versatile recipe - you can double the portions for a party.
Teachers have to be versatile to cope with different ability levels.

definitions.meaning: to look at and study a book, document, etc. carefully
examples: She spends a lot of time poring over the historical records of the church.

definitions.meaning: making you feel that something bad or evil might happen
examples: The ruined house had a sinister appearance.
A sinister-looking man sat in the corner of the room.

definitions.meaning: the hard surface of a road, a sidewalk (= path next to a road), or other area of ground
examples: The umbrella fell to the pavement with a clatter.

definitions.meaning: that is the reason or explanation for
examples: His mother was Italian, hence his name - Luca.
Peter's leaving at the end of this week - hence his anxiety to get his work finished.
The prime minister was attending the conference, hence all the extra security.
He's just got a pay rise, hence the new car.
She's just found out she failed her exams, hence her bad mood.
The firm is owned by Mark Atkins, hence the name - MA Advertising.

definitions.meaning: to hit someone, esp. a child, with the hand on the buttocks, usually as a punishment
to think about a particular subject or thing or about doing something or about whether to do something
examples: Consider Clara Barton, who founded the American Red Cross.
We considered moving to California, but decided not to.
We have to consider what to do next.

definitions.meaning: to care about or respect
examples: Before raising the admission prices, consider the fans.

definitions.meaning: to believe to be; to think of as
examples: What some people would consider a personal attack, Andy considers a friendly discussion.

definitions.meaning: easily annoyed or upset
examples: a cranky baby
He's been cranky all day.

definitions.meaning: strange and unusual
examples: She's a member of a group that promotes cranky ideas about food and exercise.

definitions.meaning: to be interested in something and be likely to do a particular activity
examples: She's not sure what she wants to do, but she's leaning towards medicine.
Games are leaning towards 3D technology.

definitions.meaning: a show of anger, worry, or excitement that is unnecessary or greater than the situation deserves
examples: She made such a fuss when Richard spilled a drop of wine on her blouse!
It's all a fuss about nothing.
I don't see what the fuss is about - he seems like a fairly ordinary-looking guy to me.
We tried to arrange a ceremony with as little fuss as possible.

definitions.meaning: attention given to small matters that are not important
examples: The article was entitled "Making up with the minimum of fuss: a five-minute beauty routine that every busy woman should know".
I felt so ashamed of myself for making such a fuss.
He kicked up a tremendous fuss about having to wait.
I can't think what's got into him. He doesn't usually make such a fuss.
God, he's such a drama queen! I've never seen such a fuss.
I grant that it must have been upsetting but even so I think she made a bit of a fuss.

definitions.meaning: to give too much attention to small matters that are not important, usually in a way that shows that you are worried and not relaxed
examples: Please, stop fussing - the food's cooking and there's nothing more to do until the guests arrive.
It irritates me the way she's always fussing with her hair!

definitions.meaning: very bad
examples: disgraceful behaviour/conduct
a disgraceful situation
She thought that their attitude was absolutely disgraceful.
It is disgraceful that children can get hold of drugs at school.

definitions.meaning: an occasion when you seem to suggest something without saying it directly
examples: From what she said, the implication was that they were splitting up.
She accused the party and, by implication, its leader too.

definitions.meaning: the effect that an action or decision will have on something else in the future
examples: The company is cutting back its spending and I wonder what the implications will be for our department.
What are the implications of the new law?
Because of security implications the officers were tried in secret.
What are the implications of his report?
The implication of her claim is that the Minister lied to Parliament.
The incident has serious security implications.
It's not yet clear what the implications of the new legislation will be for small businesses.

definitions.meaning: to use something to discover if it works or if you like it
examples: Don't forget to try out the equipment before setting up the experiment.

definitions.meaning: to use something that you already have in order to achieve something new or better
examples: We can gain a market advantage by leveraging our network of partners.

definitions.meaning: extremely important or necessary
examples: a crucial decision/question
Her work has been crucial to the project's success.
It is crucial that the problem is tackled immediately.
Price will be a crucial factor in the success of this new product.
The motif of betrayal and loss is crucial in all these stories.
The turning point in her political career came when she was chosen to fight a crucial by-election.
During the trial, the prosecution was accused of withholding crucial evidence from the defence.
The Panama Canal provides a crucial shipping link between the Atlantic and Pacific oceans.

definitions.meaning: to criticize angrily someone who has done something wrong
examples: His mother scolded him for breaking the window.
There is a girl who is being scolding by her mother

definitions.meaning: to take someone or something to a particular place, usually by car, as you travel to a different place
examples: We dropped our luggage off at the hotel and went sightseeing.
I have to drop my sister off at work before I come over.

definitions.meaning: to finally be in a particular place or situation
examples: We ended up renting a movie instead of going to the theatre.
They're travelling across Europe by train and are planning to end up in Moscow.
Much of this meat will probably end up as dog food.
She'll end up penniless if she continues to spend like that.
After working her way around the world, she ended up teaching English as a foreign language.

definitions.meaning: to fall to the ground
examples: Our apple tree fell down in the storm.
He stumbled and fell down.

definitions.meaning: If a building is falling down, it is in a very bad condition and there is a risk that it will break into pieces and drop to the ground
examples: Many buildings in the old part of the city are falling down.

definitions.meaning: to fail
examples: Where do you think the plan falls down?
The picture that you hung up last night fell down this morning.
I'm looking for a doings to hold up a curtain rail that's fallen down.
The scaffolding prevents the building from falling down.
A new steeple was built after the old one fell down.
One of the their players fell down every time someone tried to tackle him.
She fell down to her knees and prayed.

definitions.meaning: a piece of material, especially cloth, that hangs across a window or opening to make a room or part of a room dark or private
examples: Heavy curtains blocked out the sunlight.
to draw (= open or close) the curtains

definitions.meaning: a thick layer of something that makes it difficult to see anything behind it
examples: They could see nothing through the curtain of rain/smoke.
The audience was still laughing as the curtain fell.
He pulled the curtain aside.
I'm trying to match up this wallpaper with some suitable curtain material.
A coat of paint and new curtains would really cheer the kitchen up.
I peered through a chink in the curtains and saw them all inside.

definitions.meaning: to admit that you were wrong or that you have been defeated
examples: Eventually, Roberto backed down and apologized.
Local residents have forced the local council to back down from/on its plans to build a nightclub on their street.

definitions.meaning: used to say you have read or been told something although you are not certain it is true
examples: Apparently it's going to rain today.
Apparently he's had enough of England and is going back to Australia.

definitions.meaning: used when the real situation is different from what you thought it was
examples: You know I told you Alice's party was on the 13th? Well I saw her last night and apparently it's on the 14th.
She looks about ten, but apparently she's 14.
I thought they were married but apparently not (= they are not married).

definitions.meaning: used to say that something seems to be true, although it is not certain
examples: An 80-year-old woman was badly hurt in what the police describe as an apparently motiveless attack (= an attack for no apparent reason).
The train was delayed, apparently due to leaves on the line.
His resignation was apparently for personal rather than professional reasons.
He lives in Little Overington, apparently, wherever that is.
A series of apparently unconnected events led to his resignation.
I heard a rumour that she's leaving, but apparently it's not true.

definitions.meaning: to try to make someone do something for you by giving them money, presents, or something else that they want
examples: He bribed immigration officials and entered the country illegally.
They bribed the waiter to find them a better table.
He discovered that certain corrupt officials had been bribed to approve shoddy construction work.
Apparently various prominent businessmen had been bribing the minister for favours.
He bribed the children with sweets and pocket money not to tell their mum what he'd done.
"You can have my chocolate bar if you'll tell me the answer." "Are you trying to bribe me?"
They should not have been allowed over the border, but somehow they managed to bribe the guards.

definitions.meaning: money or a present that you give to someone so that they will do something for you, usually something dishonest
examples: He was accused of accepting/taking bribes from wealthy businessmen.
It was easy to see the gift as a sort of bribe.
He showed great strength of character when he refused to accept the bribes.
Greenway appeared at Bow Street Magistrates' Court to face seven charges of accepting bribes.
His political career ended when he compromised himself by accepting bribes.
The only way I can get him to do his homework is by offering him bribes.

definitions.meaning: a suggestion that something unpleasant or violent will happen, especially if a particular action or order is not followed
examples: Her parents carried out their threat to take away her mobile phone if her grades didn't improve.
The threat of jail failed to deter him from petty crime.
Drunken drivers pose a serious threat (= cause a lot of harm) to other road users.
He says he'll tell the authorities but it's just an empty threat (= it will not happen).

definitions.meaning: to be in a situation where people are threatening you with something bad or unpleasant
examples: She left the country under threat of arrest if she returned.
Nuclear weapons pose a threat to everyone.
The police have to take any terrorist threat seriously.
It is hoped that the kidnappers will not carry out their threat to kill the hostages.
Three main line railway stations were closed because of bomb threats.
The key witness for the prosecution was offered police protection after she received death threats.

definitions.meaning: extremely important or urgent
examples: The president said it was imperative that the release of all hostages be secured.
It's imperative to act now before the problem gets really serious.

definitions.meaning: used to describe the form of a verb that is usually used for giving orders
examples: In the phrase "Leave him alone!", the verb "leave" is in the imperative form.

definitions.meaning: the form of a verb that is usually used for giving orders
examples: In the phrase "Leave him alone!", the verb "leave" is an imperative/is in the imperative.

definitions.meaning: something that is extremely important or urgent
examples: Getting the unemployed back to work, said the mayor, is a moral imperative.
A sentence that is a command, such as 'Stand over there', contains an imperative.
The next lesson teaches you how to use the imperative tense of Spanish verbs correctly.

definitions.meaning: to make something bad such as pain or problems less severe
examples: The drugs did nothing to alleviate her pain/suffering.
What are some things you do to help alleviate the discomfort.

definitions.meaning: to go to bed later than usual
examples: We stayed up (late) to watch a film.

definitions.meaning: If a football team stays up, it remains in a division and is not relegated (= moved down to a lower division)
examples: I think all the newly-promoted clubs have a great chance of staying up this season.
I stayed up to watch the Olympics on television.
The kids were allowed to stay up till midnight on New Year's Eve.
I'll be late home so don't stay up waiting for me.
We stayed up till 3.00, chatting about old times.
These days if I stay up late one night I'm exhausted the next morning.

definitions.meaning: to think that you are better than someone
examples: She thinks they look down on her because she doesn't have a job.

definitions.meaning: an advantage that someone has over other people in something such as a competition or race
examples: You've got a head start over/on others trying to get the job because you've got relevant work experience.
They have a ten-year head start

definitions.meaning: A blunt pencil, knife, etc. is not sharp and therefore not able to write, cut, etc. well.
saying what you think without trying to be polite or considering other people's feelings
examples: I'll be blunt - that last piece of work you did was terrible.

definitions.meaning: unfastened
examples: Why didn't you tell me my zip was undone!
Damn, my shoe-laces have come undone again.

definitions.meaning: to be without hope for the future, having experienced great disappointment, loss of money, etc.
very pleased
examples: a delighted audience
Pat was delighted with her new house.
I was delighted at/by your news.
I'm absolutely delighted that you can come.
We'd be delighted to come to dinner on Friday.
The audience was clearly delighted with the performance.
She said she didn't care about it, but I believe she was secretly delighted.
Le Tissier was delighted when he received his England call-up.
The whole school is delighted about Joel's success in the championships.
If you'd care to bring your young man along too, we should be delighted to meet him.

definitions.meaning: careful not to cause embarrassment or attract too much attention, especially by keeping something secret
examples: The family made discreet enquiries about his background.
They are very good assistants, very discreet - they wouldn't go talking to the press.
If someone is cheating on their partner or spouse, they should be as discreet as possible so that no one finds out.
We should be discreet when talking about our work around people that are not at Yandex because we shouldn't give away any of our work secrets.
Please use discretion when talking about your work.

definitions.meaning: a request to the public for money, information, or help
examples: They're launching (= starting) an appeal to raise money for famine victims.
The police have issued an appeal to the public to stay away from the area over the weekend.

definitions.meaning: a request made to a court of law or to someone in authority to change a previous decision
examples: The case went to the court of appeal/the appeal court.
He won his appeal and the sentence was halved.
She has lodged (= made) an appeal against the severity of the fine.

definitions.meaning: the quality in someone or something that makes him, her, or it attractive or interesting
examples: sex appeal
Spielberg's movies have a wide appeal.
This used to be a marvellous hotel but it has lost its appeal in recent years.
No witnesses to the accident have come forward yet, despite the police's appeal.
The missing child's distraught parents made an emotional appeal for information on TV.
The appeal for people to donate blood was very successful.
She made an eloquent appeal for action before it was too late.
The campaign has been gaining momentum ever since the television appeal.
Lee's solicitor said last night that they would be lodging an appeal against the sentence.
The district attorney said if McVeigh is given the death penalty and his conviction is upheld on appeal, the state prosecution would become moot.
The appeal was rejected by the High Court.
The judge ordered that he post a $10 000 bond pending his appeal of the verdict.
She took her case to an immigration appeals tribunal.

definitions.meaning: to finally understand something or someone, or find the solution to a problem after a lot of thought
examples: I can't figure out why he did it.
I find him really odd - I can't figure him out at all.
Can you figure out the answer to question 5?
We need to figure out what went wrong.
It took them ages to figure out how to assemble the chest of drawers.
As soon as she figures out what happened, you're in trouble.
When you've figured the answer out, put your hand up.
They spent 20 minutes figuring out how to open the box.

definitions.meaning: to write the necessary information on an official document
examples: to fill in a form/questionnaire
I had to fill in this really complicated form.
To find out more about our products, fill in the coupon and send it to us at the address given below.
Please fill in/out the application form with black ink.
Would you mind filling in a questionnaire about what you watch on television?
Charlie never fills in the record forms, which ruins the whole ordering system.

definitions.meaning: to make something full, or to become full
examples: The sales pipeline for his facility is starting to fill up with clients.
Too many spam emails are filling up our inboxes.
I always fill the water jug up when it is empty.
I'll fill the tank up before we leave for our trip this weekend.

definitions.meaning: to get information about something because you want to know more about it, or to learn a fact or piece of information for the first time
examples: How did you find out about the party?
The holiday was a complete surprise - I only found out about it the day before we left.
I'll just go and find out what's going on outside.
Too late, she found out that the flight had been cancelled.
We don't know where he lives. How can we find out?
She found out that he'd been cheating on her.
It was when we started living together that we found we just weren't compatible.
I must find out the train times.
I must find out how much it will cost.
When he found out what we'd done he was so shocked.

definitions.meaning: to deal successfully with a difficult situation
examples: It must be really hard to cope with three young children and a job.
It's only been a year since he died - how's she coping?
He had so much pressure on him in his job that eventually he just couldn't cope.
Will she be able to cope with the work?
The hostages had been confined for so long that they couldn't cope with the outside world.
Get a good night's sleep and you'll feel better able to cope.
The teacher said that he found it difficult to cope with a class of disaffected teenagers.
The emergency services are working at full stretch today to cope with the accident.

definitions.meaning: to be brave enough to do something difficult or dangerous or that you should not do
examples: She wouldn’t dare go out alone there at night.
He wanted to touch it, but he didn’t dare.
I can’t believe you dare to talk to me this way!

definitions.meaning: to ask someone to do something that involves risk
examples: I dare you to ask him to dance.

definitions.meaning: something difficult or dangerous that you do because someone asks you to do it
examples: He jumped into the river on a dare.

definitions.meaning: working energetically and continuously
examples: Tony is a tireless worker.
The prisoner's family is conducting a tireless campaign for his release.
The police have been tireless in their search for the child's killer.

definitions.meaning: a large amount of ice, snow, and rock falling quickly down the side of a mountain
too many things that arrive or happen at the same time
examples: We were swamped by an avalanche of letters/phone calls/complaints.

definitions.meaning: to wait at a place, or to stay near a place or person, often for no particular reason
examples: We were just hanging around the mall.
She hangs around with some tough kids.
We'll probably just hang around the place/house.

definitions.meaning: to perform or complete a job or activity; to fulfill
examples: I was elected to carry out a program, the governor said, and I have every intention of carrying it out.

definitions.meaning: an occasion when an army or country uses force to enter and take control of another country
examples: They were planning to mount an invasion of the north of the country.

definitions.meaning: an occasion when a large number of people or things come to a place in an annoying and unwanted way
examples: the annual invasion of foreign tourists

definitions.meaning: an action or process that affects someone's life in an unpleasant and unwanted way
examples: an invasion of privacy
The D-Day invasion was a concerted exercise by the armed forces of Britain, the US and Canada.
The ancient Britons inhabited these parts of England before the Roman invasion.
Thousands of troops have massed along the border in preparation for an invasion.
British troops spearheaded the invasion.
The overnight invasion took the military experts unawares.

definitions.meaning: the act of watching a person or activity and making certain that everything is done correctly, safely, etc.
examples: Students are not allowed to handle these chemicals unless they are under the supervision of a teacher.
In cases of severe mental handicap, constant supervision is recommended.
The drug should only be administered under strict medical supervision.
The children were running around with no supervision.
The machine should only be used with adult supervision.
Never operate the machinery without supervision.

definitions.meaning: If something “makes your head spin,” it means it makes you extremely confused.
examples: I don’t understand the instruction manual for this computer program – all the technical jargon just makes my head spin.

definitions.meaning: to perform well enough to succeed in something:
examples: Marvin wanted to be an actor, but he didn't make the grade.

definitions.meaning: to make something dirty or untidy
examples: Who's messed up the bookshelf?
The wind had messed up my hair.
They had come along and messed up her arrangement.
I've only just tidied this room and you've messed it up already.
Who has messed up my sewing box?

definitions.meaning: to spoil or damage something, or to do something wrong or badly
examples: I messed up my chances of becoming a great singer.
He says that his divorce has really messed his life up.
You really messed up this time.
He messed up his life with drugs.
The business was going really well until Peter messed it up.
Don't mess up your marriage by working every evening.
He has messed up his chance of a good education.

definitions.meaning: to fail to use an opportunity to enjoy or get an advantage from something
examples: Don't miss out on the fantastic bargains in our summer sale.
We didn't have a TV at home when I was young, and I felt as though I missed out.

definitions.meaning: to manage to make someone understand or believe something
examples: We tried to get our point across, but he just wouldn't listen.
This is the message that we want to get across to the public.
The novel is good at getting the experience of war across to the reader.
The campaign had clearly failed to get its message across to the public.
The speaker reiterated the main points he was trying to get across to the audience.
Do you think he managed to get his ideas across?
She usually wastes no time in getting her points across.
I tried to get my point across to the judge but she wouldn't listen.

definitions.meaning: to have a good relationship
examples: We're getting on much better now that we don't live together.
He doesn't get on with his daughter.

definitions.meaning: to manage or deal with a situation, especially successfully
examples: How are you getting on in your new home?
We're getting on quite well with the decorating.

definitions.meaning: to continue doing something, especially work
examples: I'll leave you to get on then, shall I?

definitions.meaning: to be getting old
examples: He's getting on (a bit) - he'll be 76 next birthday.

definitions.meaning: If you say it's getting on, or time is getting on, you mean it is becoming late
examples: It's getting on - we'd better be going.

definitions.meaning: almost
examples: He must be getting on for 80 now.
It was getting on for midnight.
We haven't been getting on recently.
It's important that you get on with your colleagues.
Do you get on with your brother?
They got on better when they were children.
He gets on with everyone.
How are you getting on with your essay?
How are you getting on with your new car?
He seems to be getting on well in his new job.
How did you get on with the questions I set you?
I'll have to wait for the results to see how I got on with my exams.
I'd better not stop now, I need to get on.
He must be getting on a bit now.
My dad would love to help but he's getting on a bit now.
I should think he's into his eighties by now - he's getting on.
You forget - I'm getting on. I'm not as young as I used to be.
I suppose they're getting on now and they've had various friends die.

definitions.meaning: to leave or escape from a person or place, often when it is difficult to do this
examples: We walked to the next beach to get away from the crowds.
I'll get away from work as soon as I can.

definitions.meaning: to go somewhere to have a holiday, often because you need to rest
examples: I just need to get away for a few days.
We've decided to go to hiking in the mountains to get away from it all.
I had to get away from the party. It was awful.
They got away from burning car before it exploded.
I finally got away from work at eight o'clock.
We're getting away in January for a skiing holiday.
By the time the police arrived, the robbers had got away.

definitions.meaning: to injure a muscle by stretching it too far so that it is very painful
examples: Russell pulled a back muscle early in the game.
He pulled a muscle in his groin.
I pulled a muscle in my back lifting some drawers.

definitions.meaning: Run-down buildings or areas are in very bad condition
examples: a run-down building/cemetery

definitions.meaning: tired and not healthy, especially because of working too much
examples: My doctor said I was looking run-down.

definitions.meaning: not at all
examples: It is by no means certain that we'll finish the project by June.
This isn't the last we'll hear of it by any means.
